abstract.t: This document defines the JSON schema for using DSA algorithms with the ACVP specification.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing DSA algorithms using ACVP.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted in RFC 2119.

section.title: Capabilities Registration
section.t: ACVP requires crypto modules to register their capabilities. This allows the crypto module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of DSA algorithms to the ACVP server.

The algorithm capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algorithms' value of the ACVP registration message. The 'algorithms' value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The 'algorithms' value is part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.

section.title: Required Prerequisite Algorithms for DSA Validations
section.t: Each DSA implementation relies on other cryptographic primitives. For example, DSA uses an underlying SHA algorithm. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

texttable.title: Required DSA Prerequisite Algorithms JSON Values
texttable.c: object with algorithm and valValue properties

section.title: DSA Algorithm Capabilities Registration
section.t: Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values.

texttable.title: DSA Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The DSA mode to be validated
array of JSON objects, each with fields pertaining to the global DSA mode indicated above and identified uniquely by the combination of the DSA "mode" and indicated properties

section.title: Supported DSA Modes Capabilities
section.t: The DSA mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algSpecs' value of the ACVP registration message - see . The 'algSpecs' value is an array, where each array element is a JSON object corresponding to a particular DSA mode defined in this section. The 'algSpecs' value is part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each DSA mode's capabilities are advertised as JSON objects.

section.title: The pqgGen Mode Capabilities
section.t: The DSA pqgGen mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects, which are elements of the 'algSpecs' array in the ACVP registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each DSA pqgGen mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: pqgGen Full Set of Capabilities
section.t: The complete list of DSA pqg generation capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: DSA pqgGen Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The length in bits of the field and the length in bits of prime p.
The length in bits of q which is a prime factor of (p-1).
The methods supported to generate p and q.
The methods supported to generate g.
The hash functions supported when generating p, q and g.
Any non-empty subset of {"SHA2-224", "SHA2-256", "SHA2-384", "SHA2-512", "SHA2-512/224", "SHA2-512/256"}. Note that the digest size of the hash function MUST be equal to or greater than N.

section.title: The pqgVer Mode Capabilities
section.t: The DSA pqgVer mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects, which are elements of the 'algSpecs' array in the ACVP registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each DSA pqgVer mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: pqgVer Full Set of Capabilities
section.t: The complete list of DSA pqg verification capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: DSA pqgVer Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The length in bits of the field and the length in bits of prime p.
The length in bits of q which is a prime factor of (p-1).
160 when L is 1024. 224, or 256 when L is 2048. Otherwise 256.
The methods supported to generate p and q.
The methods supported to generate g.
The hash functions supported when generating p, q and g.
Any non-empty subset of {"SHA-1", "SHA2-224", "SHA2-256", "SHA2-384", "SHA2-512", "SHA2-512/224", "SHA2-512/256"}. Note that the digest size of the hash function MUST be equal to or greater than N.

section.title: The keyGen Mode Capabilities
section.t: The DSA keyGen mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects, which are elements of the 'algSpecs' array in the ACVP registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each DSA keyGen mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: keyGen Full Set of Capabilities
section.t: The complete list of DSA key generation capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: DSA keyGen Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The length in bits of the field and the length in bits of prime p.
The length in bits of q which is a prime factor of (p-1).

section.title: The sigGen Mode Capabilities
section.t: The DSA sigGen mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects, which are elements of the 'algSpecs' array in the ACVP registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each DSA sigGen mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: sigGen Full Set of Capabilities
section.t: The complete list of DSA signature generation capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: DSA sigGen Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The length in bits of the field and the length in bits of prime p.
The length in bits of q which is a prime factor of (p-1).
The hash functions supported when signing a message.

section.title: The sigVer Mode Capabilities
section.t: The DSA sigVer mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects, which are elements of the 'algSpecs' array in the ACVP registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each DSA sigVer mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: sigVer Full Set of Capabilities
section.t: The complete list of DSA signature verification capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: DSA sigVer Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The length in bits of the field and the length in bits of prime p.
The length in bits of q which is a prime factor of (p-1).
160 when L is 1024. 224, or 256 when L is 2048. Otherwise 256.
The hash functions supported when verifying a message.

section.title: Test Vectors
section.t: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual DSA function. This section describes the JSON schema for a test vector set used with DSA algorithms.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client.The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

texttable.title: Vector Set JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
The DSA mode used for the test vectors.
Array of test group JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Groups JSON Schema
section.t: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the secure hash JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.
The test group for DSA is as follows:

texttable.title: Vector Group JSON Object
texttable.c: Length in bits of prime modulus p
Length in bits of prime divisor q
The hash algorithm used in the test group
The specific pq generation mode used in the test group
The specific g generation mode used in the test group
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Case JSON Schema
section.t: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each DSA test vector.

texttable.title: Test Case JSON Object
texttable.c: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set.
The seed used to generate p and q in the probable method
The counter used to generate p and q in the probable method
The seed used to generate p in the provable method
The seed used to generate q in the provable method
The counter used to generate p in the provable method
The counter used to generate q in the provable method
The index value provided to the g generator in the unverifiable method
The index value provided to the g generator in the canonical method
The message used to generate signature or verify signature

section.title: Test Vector Responses
section.t: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it must send the response vectors back to the ACVP server. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

texttable.title: Vector Set Response JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of JSON objects that represent each test vector result, as defined by the tables below

section.t: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response for DSA.

texttable.title: Vector Set Response JSON Object
texttable.c: The seed used to generate p and q in the probable method
The counter used to generate p and q in the probable method
The seed used to generate p in the provable method
The seed used to generate q in the provable method
The counter used to generate p in the provable method
The counter used to generate q in the provable method
The pass or fail result of the verify

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This memo includes no request to IANA.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Security considerations are addressed by the ACVP specification.

section.title: Example DSA JSON Object
section.t: The following sections contain example JSON for the various DSA modes: keyPair, sigGen, sigVer, pqgGen and pqgVer. Note that all binary HEX representations are in big-endian format.

section.title: Example DSA PQGGen Capabilities JSON Object
section.t: The following is a example JSON object advertising support for DSA pqgGen.

section.t: The following is a example JSON object for DSA SigVer, test vectors sent from the ACVP server to the crypto module and the response.
